results.title: New voices
results.creator_credit: James Beveridge and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “The Crossroads of the world: a study of North Africa and the Middle East”.
In a world where the fortunes of one people crisscross with others, it is to be expected that the voices of Muslim countries will be raised on world issues. At the United Nations and other international gatherings, this film watches and listens to the new leaders of the Islamic world. What you see and hear has much meaning for you, and even more significance for the new African nations among whom Islam is a live and growing force.

results.title: New uses for Seaweed
results.brief_description: A brief account of the uses to which alginates, which are obtained from seaweed, are being put - from foodstuffs to toothpaste. A fine synthetic fibre, spun from the jelly is used in the manufacture of light-weight woollen materials.

results.title: New uses for coal waste
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
At the present level of coal usage a mountainous 15 million tonnes of waste is left behind every year after the coal is washed. Most of the waste is a coarse coal-bearing shale which is dumped in slag heaps. A program to reduce and utilise the waste from coal washeries has come up with far-reaching economic possibilities. The film looks at these possibilities.

results.title: New universities
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Look at Life”.
A survey of the new universities program which seeks to extend facilities for university training in England. Taking the University of Sussex as the principal example, the film gives a picture of student life and activities in the fine modern buildings designed by Sir Basil Spence.

results.title: New twists on ocean currents
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
Fibreglass buoys floating in the ocean are used to track the huge ocean currents off the coast of New South Wales. The buoys are proving highly reliable in supplying insights into the so-called East Australian currents.

results.title: New town
results.creator_credit: British Information Services and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Commonwealth Teleview”.
Commonwealth Teleview Series - Visiting Harlow, a British satellite town, Christopher Chataway discusses this ‘modern’ building phenomenon with Frederick Gibberd, the city’s architect-planner. Chataway also interviews people living and working in the town, obtaining their views on this experiment in town planning.

results.title: New town
results.creator_credit: Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films, John Halas and Joy Batchelor
results.brief_description: A cartoon film explaining the need for town planning to avoid a repetition of past mistakes. Diagrams illustrate how towns have grown without provision being made for proper transport, for the separation of industrial and residential areas and the provision of playgrounds and conveniently situated shopping centres.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films, John Halas and Joy Batchelor

results.title: New tools for learning
results.creator_credit: Bernard Berelson and Audio-Visual Center of University of Chicago
results.brief_description: Shows how the film, together with a wide range of other materials, can bring richness and greater vitality to teaching. Effective methods of classroom use of films are demonstrated through scenes showing pupils and teachers at work in school situation, at junior and senior high school and also university level. The importance of the use of a wide range of instructional materials in the tremendous task of education is stressed.

results.title: New Technology, Whose Progress? (TEFC)
results.brief_description: A critical examination of the micro and the claim that we are witnessing a twentieth century technological revolution. Presents arguments that are being developed by critics of the new technology
